body:
### Problem

Got a weird keymap issue.

I'm running neovim in tmux and I have these keymaps:

`~/.config/nvim/lua/core/keymaps.lua`
```lua
--[[ Pastebins ]]
--
vim.keymap.set('n', '<leader>pp', ':!paste-pick -p %<CR>', { desc = 'paste file to paste.c-net.org' }) -- paste.c-net.org
vim.keymap.set('n', '<leader>pt', ':!paste-pick -t %<CR>', { desc = 'paste file to termbin.com' }) -- termbin.com
vim.keymap.set('n', '<leader>pn', ':!paste-pick -z %<CR>', { desc = 'paste file to 0x0.st' }) -- 0x0.st

vim.keymap.set({ 'v', 'x' }, '<leader>pp', ':w !paste-pick -p<CR>', { desc = 'paste lines to paste.c-net.org' }) -- paste.c-net.org
vim.keymap.set({ 'v', 'x' }, '<leader>pt', ':w !paste-pick -t<CR>', { desc = 'paste lines to termbin.com' }) -- termbin.com 
vim.keymap.set({ 'v', 'x' }, '<leader>pn', ':w !paste-pick -z<CR>', { desc = 'paste lines to 0x0.st' }) -- 0x0.st
```

I would expect that in visual mode, that second block of maps would apply and
only paste my selected lines. Instead, it pastes the whole file. If I select
just one line, only that line gets pasted. But if I select multiple, neovim
runs the command assigned to the normal mode mapping.

I notice the map tries to do the whole file unless I open an addional tmux pane.
or otherwise reload neovim. In that new pane, all the neovim buffers handle this
map as I have it set. The maps have been set since the before times, before I
was using tmux that is.

video demonstration:
https://0x0.st/Kuvk.mp4 - "dirty" config
https://0x0.st/K2V4.mp4 - first "dirty" then clean config

### Steps to reproduce

1. established the aforementioned keymaps in
   `~/.config/nvim/lua/core/keymaps.lua`
2. Source file in `~/.config/nvim/init.lua` via `require 'core.keymaps'`
3. Open neovim under a tmux session
4. Select a range of lines in a file and attempt one of the visual mode keymaps
5. Observe that the command is applied to the entire file instead of the selected lines
6. Open a new window in the same tmux session and repeat step 4
7. Observe that the keymap works as defined

### Expected behavior

Neovim repsects the keymap regardless of which tmux window it's opened under.

### Config
#### Dirty (excerpt)

`~/.config/nvim/lua/core/keymaps.lua `

```lua
--[[ Pastebins ]]
--
vim.keymap.set('n', '<leader>pp', ':!paste-pick -p %<CR>', { desc = 'paste file to paste.c-net.org' }) -- paste.c-net.org
vim.keymap.set('n', '<leader>pt', ':!paste-pick -t %<CR>', { desc = 'paste file to termbin.com' }) -- termbin.com
vim.keymap.set('n', '<leader>pn', ':!paste-pick -z %<CR>', { desc = 'paste file to 0x0.st' }) -- 0x0.st

vim.keymap.set({ 'v', 'x' }, '<leader>pp', ':w !paste-pick -p<CR>', { desc = 'paste lines to paste.c-net.org' }) -- paste.c-net.org
vim.keymap.set({ 'v', 'x' }, '<leader>pt', ':w !paste-pick -t<CR>', { desc = 'paste lines to termbin.com' }) -- termbin.com 
vim.keymap.set({ 'v', 'x' }, '<leader>pn', ':w !paste-pick -z<CR>', { desc = 'paste lines to 0x0.st' }) -- 0x0.st
```

`~/.config/nvim/init.lua`

```lua
print 'config sourced'

require 'core.lazy'

require 'core.options'
require 'core.keymaps'
require 'core.floating-terminal'
```

#### clean
`~/.config/nvim/init.lua`

```lua
vim.g.mapleader = ' '
vim.g.maplocalleader = ' '

--[[ Pastebins ]]
--
vim.keymap.set('n', '<leader>pp', ':!paste-pick -p %<CR>', { desc = 'paste file to paste.c-net.org' }) -- paste.c-net.org
vim.keymap.set('n', '<leader>pt', ':!paste-pick -t %<CR>', { desc = 'paste file to termbin.com' }) -- termbin.com
vim.keymap.set('n', '<leader>pn', ':!paste-pick -z %<CR>', { desc = 'paste file to 0x0.st' }) -- 0x0.st

vim.keymap.set({ 'v', 'x' }, '<leader>pp', ':w !paste-pick -p<CR>', { desc = 'paste lines to paste.c-net.org' }) -- paste.c-net.org
vim.keymap.set({ 'v', 'x' }, '<leader>pt', ':w !paste-pick -t<CR>', { desc = 'paste lines to termbin.com' }) -- termbin.com
vim.keymap.set({ 'v', 'x' }, '<leader>pn', ':w !paste-pick -z<CR>', { desc = 'paste lines to 0x0.st' }) -- 0x0.st

```

### Nvim version (nvim -v)

NVIM v0.11.3

### Vim (not Nvim) behaves the same?

This is more of a neovim thing due to the nature of lua keymaps

### Operating system/version

Debian GNU/Linux 13.1 (trixie)

### Terminal name/version

foot version: 1.24.0-2-gc34f0633 (Sep 14 2025, branch 'master') +pgo +ime +graphemes -assertions

### $TERM environment variable

TERM=xterm-256color

### Installation

build from repo

comment_data.body:
No idea what `paste-pick` is, but just guessing that maybe it cares about the tmux window or something like that.

The issue tracker is for self-contained steps, not "help me debug my config" questions.

Ask questions about usage and configuration here:

- https://github.com/neovim/neovim/discussions
- https://vi.stackexchange.com

@justinmk 
The issue is that nvim is behaving differently than the keymaps what has been set.

If you look at the keymaps, you'll see one set  (normal map) uses `':!paste-pick'` and the other (visual) uses `':w !paste-pick'`

the latter is supposed to populate the command line with `:'<,'>w`

You can see in the video that it doesn't do that unless I re-open neovim in the same tmux window or in a new one

paste-pick

```fish
#! /usr/bin/fish
# Defined via `source`
function usage
    echo "Usage: paste-pick [-h] [-p] [-t] [-z] file"
    echo "-h                Show this help page"
    echo "-p                Paste to paste.c-net.org"
    echo "-t                Paste to termbin.com"
    echo "-z                Paste to 0x0.st"
end

function paste-pick --argument option package
    if test (count $argv) -gt 2
        echo "Too many arguments passed. See paste-pick --help for usage"
        return 1
    else if ! test -f $argv[2]
        echo "Invalid or non-existent file. See paste-pick --help for usage"
        return 1
    else if test (count $argv) -le 2
        switch $argv[1]
            case -h --help
                usage
                return 0
        end
        set filename (basename "$package")
        # store filename and extension in array
        set ext (string split . (basename "$package"))
        set tmpfile "tmpfile.$ext[2]"

        echo $filename >$tmpfile
        cat $package >>$tmpfile

        switch $option
            case -p
                pc cat $tmpfile
                rm -rf $tmpfile
                return 0
            case -t
                tb cat $tmpfile
                rm -rf $tmpfile
                return 0
            case -z
                bz $tmpfile
                rm -rf $tmpfile
            case '' '*'
                echo 'Unknown option. See paste-pick --help for Usage'
                return 1
        end
    end
end
```

bz (aka binzero; paste to 0x0.st)
```fish
function binzero --wraps='curl -F"file=@$argv" https://0x0.st' --description 'curl -F"file=@$argv" https://0x0.st'
    set -l output (curl --user-agent "curl/8.13.0" -F"file=@$argv" -Fexpires=8 https://0x0.st)
    printf '%s\n' $output
    printf '%s' $output | wl-copy
end
```

pc (paste to paste.c-net.org)
```fish
function pc --wraps='yo mamma' --description 'paste to paste.c-net-org'
    set -l output ($argv | nc paste.c-net.org 9999)
    printf '%s\n' $output
    printf '%s' $output | wl-copy
end
```

tb (paste to termbin)
```fish
function tb
    set -l output ($argv | nc termbin.com 9999)
    printf '%s\n' $output
    printf '%s' $output | wl-copy
end
```

You can see from the code that paste-pick has no affiliation to tmux.

The command shouldn't matter but instead the fact that when I highlight lines and run my keymap, nvim _sometimes_ does `:'<,'> <command>` and _other_ times does `:<command>` under the same conditions.

It should only do `:'<,'> <command>` in visual mode correct?

> The command shouldn't matter but the fact that when I highlight lines and run my keymap, nvim _sometimes_ does `:'<,'> <command>` and _other_ times does `:<command>` under the same conditions.

If the command doesn't matter, don't include it in the reproduction steps - it only adds unnecessary moving parts.
If another tool is involved (like tmux), you should also mention its configuration and confirm whether a clean tmux session can reproduce the issue. But I didn't see you even restart it.

It's much more probable that the issue comes from your configuration than from tmux magically interfering with Neovim's keymap handling. A minimal reproduction will clearly show whether the problem is in your setup or the tool itself

@skewb1k 
Thank you! 
I don't know that the command _doesn't_ matter. I just don't _think_ it _should_. The command in question is how I initially discovered the issue.
To me it seems Neovim is running a normal mapping for some reason when it should be running a visual one.

Thanks for your input!
I will retest with a blank tmux config and some shell built-ins and upload a video with a larger font size.

My current tmux config:
```sh
# general
set -g prefix M-Space
# set -g send-prefix M-Space
set -g base-index 1
setw -g pane-base-index 1
set -g mode-keys vi
set -g status-keys vi
set -g renumber-windows on
set-hook -g session-created "run ~/.local/bin/renumber-session.sh"
set-hook -g session-closed "run ~/.local/bin/renumber-session.sh"
set -g history-limit 5000
set -g repeat-time 1000
set -g visual-activity on
# set -g prefix º

# terminal
set -g xterm-keys on
set -g extended-keys always
set -g extended-keys-format xterm
set -g default-terminal "xterm-256color"
set -g terminal-features ',xterm-256color:RGB:extkeys'

# unbind S-Esc

# --- binds ---
bind r source-file "~/.config/tmux/tmux.conf"; display "Sourced"
bind d run-shell "tmux neww ~/.local/bin/tmux-session-search.sh"

# sessions
bind Ñ switch-client -l
bind c new

# windows

bind $ command-prompt -I "#S" { rename-session "%%" }
bind -n M-i previous-window
bind -n M-o next-window
bind p previous-window
bind n next-window
bind ñ last-window

bind o new-window -c "#{pane_current_path}"
bind b split-window -h -c "#{pane_current_path}"
bind v split-window -v -c "#{pane_current_path}"
bind < swap-window -dt -1
bind > swap-window -dt 1

bind j command-prompt -T 'target' {join-pane -s "%%" }

bind -n M-1 select-window -t :1
bind -n M-2 select-window -t :2
bind -n M-3 select-window -t :3
bind -n M-4 select-window -t :4
bind -n M-5 select-window -t :5
bind -n M-6 select-window -t :6
bind -n M-7 select-window -t :7
bind -n M-8 select-window -t :8
bind -n M-9 select-window -t :9


# panes

# resize
bind f resize-pane -Z
bind -n C-Up resize-pane -U
bind -n C-Down resize-pane -D
bind -n C-Left resize-pane -L
bind -n C-Right resize-pane -R
bind -n M-Left
bind -n M-Right
unbind -n M-S-K
unbind -n M-S-J
unbind -n C-S->
unbind -n C-S-<
unbind -n M-S-.
unbind -n M-S-,
unbind -n 'M-S-.'
unbind -n 'M-S-,'
unbind -n 'M-S-:'
unbind -n 'M-S-;'
unbind -n 'M-:'
unbind -n 'M-;'
bind -n M-Left
bind -n M-Right

# swap panes
bind enter next-layout
bind -n M-Up swap-pane -dU
bind -n M-Down swap-pane -dD

# switch panes
bind -n C-h select-pane -L 
bind -n C-j select-pane -D 
bind -n C-k select-pane -U 
bind -n C-l select-pane -R 
bind \' switch-client -t '{marked}'


# Smart pane switching with awareness of Vim splits.
# See: https://github.com/christoomey/vim-tmux-navigator

# decide whether we're in a Vim process
is_vim="ps -o state= -o comm= -t '#{pane_tty}' \
    | grep -iqE '^[^TXZ ]+ +(\\S+\\/)?g?(view|n?vim?x?)(diff)?$'"

bind -n 'C-h' if-shell "$is_vim" 'send-keys C-h' 'select-pane -L'
bind -n 'C-j' if-shell "$is_vim" 'send-keys C-j' 'select-pane -D'
bind -n 'C-k' if-shell "$is_vim" 'send-keys C-k' 'select-pane -U'
bind -n 'C-l' if-shell "$is_vim" 'send-keys C-l' 'select-pane -R'

tmux_version='$(tmux -V | sed -En "s/^tmux ([0-9]+(.[0-9]+)?).*/\1/p")'

if-shell -b '[ "$(echo "$tmux_version < 3.0" | bc)" = 1 ]' \
    "bind-key -n 'C-\\' if-shell \"$is_vim\" 'send-keys C-\\'  'select-pane -l'"
if-shell -b '[ "$(echo "$tmux_version >= 3.0" | bc)" = 1 ]' \
    "bind-key -n 'C-\\' if-shell \"$is_vim\" 'send-keys C-\\\\'  'select-pane -l'"

bind-key -n 'M-Space' if-shell "$is_vim" 'send-keys C-Space' 'select-pane -t:.+'

bind -T copy-mode-vi 'C-h' select-pane -L
bind -T copy-mode-vi 'C-j' select-pane -D
bind -T copy-mode-vi 'C-k' select-pane -U
bind -T copy-mode-vi 'C-l' select-pane -R
bind -T copy-mode-vi 'C-ñ' select-pane -l
bind -T copy-mode-vi 'M-Space' select-pane -t:.+

# --- copy mode ---

bind -T copy-mode-vi v send-keys -X begin-selection
bind -T copy-mode-vi y send-keys -X copy-pipe-and-cancel "wl-copy"
bind -T copy-mode-vi C-q send-keys -X rectangle-toggle

# --- aesthetic ---

# color

setw -g clock-mode-colour yellow

# status bar
set -g status-style "bg=default"
set -g window-status-current-style "fg=white bold bg=default bold"
set -g window-status-bell-style "fg=red,nobold"
set -g window-style "bg=default"
set -g status-justify absolute-centre
set -g status-position top
set -g status-left "#S"
# set -g status-right ""
set -g status-right ' #{?client_prefix,#[noreverse] ,}'

# window
set -g window-status-format " #W "
set -g window-status-current-format " #W "

source-file '/home/fugue/.config/wallust/templates/tmux_colors'
```

Now I can't repro on the fully clean config _or_ the "dirty" one even though it's cleary visible in both videos.

Clean config:
```sh
tmux -f /dev/null
nvim --clean -u min.lua
```

Forgive my noobosity but if this is a runtime thing that happens after some time, how could I track that? Where might I look?

I rarely turn this machine off and constantly have tmux[neovim] running.

Thanks

@skewb1k 
Apologies for the ping.
I've uploaded a new test wherein I run tmux and neovim cleanly and include a restart. 

I don't know how I can prove this, but I believe this issue happens after the neovim session has been running a while (i.e. runtime bug). I don't how to document that via video or text however. Would you have any suggestions?

I've also posted about this [here](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/discussions/36328#discussioncomment-14788552) and have implemented the suggestion but time will tell if it works.

If this is inappropriate, please let me know and I will desist posting here and continue the discussion there.

Thank you for your consideration.

## new test
In this video I run tmux and neovim on a clean config in both a new pane and new session.
You can see in session 0 window 0, the issue persists. The issue is not present in session 2 window 0 or any other session 0 windows.

I run tmux with a clean config `tmux -f /dev/null` and neovim as well `nvim --clean -u min.lua`

#### min.lua
```lua
vim.g.mapleader = " "
vim.g.maplocalleader = " "

--[[ Pastebins ]]
--
vim.keymap.set("n", "<leader>pp", ":!paste-pick -p %<CR>", { desc = "paste file to paste.c-net.org" }) -- paste.c-net.org
vim.keymap.set("n", "<leader>pt", ":!paste-pick -t %<CR>", { desc = "paste file to termbin.com" }) -- termbin.com
vim.keymap.set("n", "<leader>pn", ":!paste-pick -z %<CR>", { desc = "paste file to 0x0.st" }) -- 0x0.st

vim.keymap.set({ "v", "x" }, "<leader>pp", ":w !paste-pick -p<CR>", { desc = "paste lines to paste.c-net.org" }) -- paste.c-net.org
vim.keymap.set({ "v", "x" }, "<leader>pt", ":w !paste-pick -t<CR>", { desc = "paste lines to termbin.com" }) -- termbin.com
vim.keymap.set({ "v", "x" }, "<leader>pn", ":w !paste-pick -z<CR>", { desc = "paste lines to 0x0.st" }) -- 0x0.st
``` 

## Video
https://0x0.st/K2kQ.mp4

@justinmk @skewb1k 
Here's a clearer picture of what's happening:
https://0x0.st/K_Nc.mp4

I demo in the video that virtually any keymap has this problem.
The first video might be kinda on the quiet side but it has audio and the screen is blown up to show my keypresses and editor more clearly. Also you can ignore the part about not having video of the cleaned configs. I have that video here:

https://0x0.st/K2Fu.mp4

Is there a way we can reopen this issue? Or should I make a new one?

Thank you for your time

labels.description: issues that are closed as usage questions
labels.name: closed:question

title: Neovim executes keymaps differently based on tmux window number
